awd_titl_txt: CRII: SHF: RUI: Representing and Merging Diverse Goal Models in Requirements Engineering
awd_abstract_narration:
Goal-Oriented Requirements Engineering (GORE) is an established method to help involved parties ("stakeholders") capture and determine the early-context for a new or modified software product. Through a central artifact called a goal model, engineers visualize the goals and dependencies of both the system under consideration and the project stakeholders. By creating goal models, engineers can reason about project trade-offs and how stakeholder goals and dependencies may evolve. Prior work assumes that only a single individual creates a goal model. This project has two research objectives. First, the project aims to enable multiple modelers to gather features from stakeholders separately and merge them into a single model for analysis. By merging goal models, practitioners may collaborate and capture additional perspectives leading to a more complete representation of the project, with inconsistencies and conflicts being resolved in the process.  Second, the project aims to improve the usability of trade-off analysis and make analysis techniques more accessible to stakeholders. By providing stakeholders with more realistic models, practitioners can make better informed decisions, which in turn provides society with higher quality software. The project will contribute to the teaching of GORE modeling, an important part of software-engineering education. 

In this project, the investigators aim to support stakeholders' ability to collaborate in GORE activities, specifically the creation and analysis of large goal models. Researchers investigate integrating the viewpoints of multiple stakeholders for models with timing information by merging model syntax and model semantics. In a second research activity, the investigators improve the interpretation of analysis results and define a methodology for applying GORE reasoning, which supports stakeholders in decision making. For example, this project combines color visualizations with filtering analysis results to narrow the state-space of potential solutions. The project will provide tool support for model-management features, such as traceability links to validate the provenance of the merge operation. The research team will validate the effectiveness of the merge operation and analysis visualization through empirical observations of modelers.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Goal-oriented requirements engineering is a method to help involved parties ("stakeholders") capture and determine the early context for a new or modified software product. Through a central artifact called a goal model, engineers visualize and reason about the goals and dependencies of both the system under consideration and the project stakeholders. By creating goal models, engineers can reason about project trade-offs and how stakeholder goals and dependencies may evolve. This project facilitates collaboration in the early stages of a project, where success depends on capturing the goals of all stakeholders.

Prior work assumed that only a single individual creates a goal model. This project enabled multiple engineers to gather features from stakeholders separately and merge them into a single model for analysis. By merging goal models, practitioners may collaborate and capture additional perspectives, leading to a more complete representation of the project. Researchers investigated merging goal models with and without evolutionary information, and proposed a formal approach to the problem of semi-automatically merging the attributes of model elements, once these elements have been matched. When models are merged, the visual layout is meaningless and needs to be updated; thus, the research team developed a layout algorithm for goal models. 

This project made analysis techniques more accessible to stakeholders, allowing them to make better-informed decisions. In the research tool used in this project (called BloomingLeaf), stakeholders can create time-based simulations to ask and answer "what if" questions. The "single-path" analysis allows them to see future states of their model, while the "next-state" analysis enables users to generate their own paths by exploring all possible next states repeatedly. As the model becomes bigger, the complexity of these simulations grows exponentially. This project investigated how stakeholders engage with models, and improved the interpretability of simulation results. Researchers added colors to assist users in identifying the various labels applied to model elements, with specialized color palettes for international and color vision deficient users. After generating a single-path simulation, engineers and stakeholders can step through the simulation viewing the evaluation labels as colors. Researchers develop multiple color overlays, which allow engineers to get a general impression of the simulation results without stepping through each state. In the next state view, researchers developed model filters (e.g., most goals satisfied), which enabled users to reduce the number of possible next states, and introduced the use of value-based filtering and coloring to assist users in understanding a solution space and customizing their project outcomes. 

This project provided tool support for model-management features in BloomingLeaf, such as enabling engineers to specify the presence of model elements over time and traceability links to validate the provenance of the merge operation. The research team validated the effectiveness of the merge operation and analysis visualization through empirical observations of students. Researchers found that the use of color as a visualization technique significantly improved the time required for analysis of goal models and did not hinder the correctness of analysis results. Finally, researchers developed a methodology to guide new users through the steps required to create and analyze a goal model in BloomingLeaf. 

The outcomes of this project permit engineers to elicit requirements from additional users, leading to the consideration of a more diverse set of intentions and more inclusive designs for software. By providing stakeholders with richer models, they can make more informed decisions, which in turn provides society with higher quality software. 

This research in improving decision making directly helps the teaching of goal modeling, an important part of software engineering education. By making analysis techniques more accessible, researchers have removed barriers for students to learn and apply goal modeling techniques in their course work and enabled students to collaborate on capstone projects. The validation work in the project has led to the creation of new open-access educational and training materials for goal modeling instruction. 

This award has increased the participation of women in computer science. Twenty-four undergraduate research students participated in the project; many come from underrepresented groups, including first-generation students. Each student participated in enhanced research training, technical skill development, and peer mentoring and leadership opportunities.
